titleStmt.title: George Colman's Comments Written on the Back of the first leaf of Act the Fifth in Mitford's Charles I Manuscript

You can have multiple notes here.

msIdentifier.idno: Add MS 42873, folio page 480 [back of sheet]

msDesc.head: George Colman's Commentary written on the back of the first leaf of Act the Fifth of Mitford's Charles I.

support.p: Paper verso side of Mitford's manuscript page

supportDesc.condition: complete and initialed by G. C.

editorialDecl.p: The writer's spelling and punctuation are retained, except where a word is split at the end of a line and the beginning of the next in the manuscript. Where the spelling and hyphenation of words deviates from the standard, in order to facilitate searching we are using the TEI elements “choice,” “sic,” and “reg” to encode both the writer's spelling and the regular international standard of Oxford English spelling, following the first listed spelling in the Oxford English Dictionary. The long s and ligatured forms are not encoded.

div.p: 'King Charles the 1st. Historl. Trag. by W. Havard, 8.vo. 1737. This piece was performed in the theatre in Lincoln's Inn Fields with very good success; & indeed there are some parts of it which seem to approach as near to the style of Shakespeare, as any of the attempts that have been made to imitate him. Some of the Characters are well drawn, & the catastrophe is pathetick and affecting. Lord Chesterfield, in his Speech on the Licencing Act, [of which Act His Lordship was a violent opponent] mentioning this Play, Says,"the catastrophe was too recent, too melancholy, & too solemn in nature to be heard of anywhere but in a pulpit."'
It is to be remembered that the above Play was acted before The Lord Chamberlain's control over Drama was established, by Act of Parliament. G. C.
